Overall, I’d call it a solid mid-tier ARPG experience. Not bad, not amazing; somewhere in middle.

The combat system feels decent at first, but you soon realize the targeting and hit registration are super clunky, especially in melee. Enemies only show their health bars when you hover over them, which gets irritating fast; there really should be an option to keep them permanently visible. I can’t even imagine playing this as a ranged character with how easily the cursor loses focus in chaotic fights.

The difficulty curve is all over the place: one minute you’re mowing through enemies, the next you’re getting demolished. By Act III and IV, it feels like the game flips a switch and suddenly expects you to have near-perfect resistances and defensive layering to survive. My Conqueror build (Warfare & Defense) went from unstoppable to squishy with the snap of a finger, until I adjusted with a shield and better resist gear. Once I did, it became somewhat satisfying again; but the spikes are insane.

The story is pretty typical for the genre, ancient evils, world-ending calamity, and you the hero rising to stop the chaos. Nothing groundbreaking, but the mythological settings across Greece, Egypt, Asia, and the Underworld are still fun (although the transition to Asia in this was super weird). The music and atmosphere are solid, and the fact that the game supports co-op multiplayer adds a nice replayability factor if you want to run it with friends or try different mastery combos.

All that said, it still has that old-school charm. Building your character, watching your skills evolve, and mowing through hordes of monsters with loot raining everywhere, that loop still works. Titan Quest 1 is a classic ARPG that shows its age in controls and pacing but remains enjoyable if you like deep character builds and mythological settings. Catch it on sale.

Two disclaimers before I start my rant: If giving mixed score was possible in Steam reviews I would rather choose that instead. Also, my 'review' is based on melee character (conqueror) gameplay.

One of my biggest gripes with this otherwise pretty decent game is that it sometimes feels incredibly clunky. What I mean is you are forced to use 'Stationary Attack' button if you want to relatively reliably target and hit enemies that are either small or very mobile (and sometimes also large ones due to much smaller hitbox than what you would expect). Another clunkiness example would be that character stops attacking (while holding LMB) after using War Horn skill - you can see where I'm going - you need to retarget enemies which can be a hassle (and you waste all the precious time during which enemies are stunned). I've also had an impression that it's way harder to target enemies when entering Colossus Form.
There is also a bunch of other minor, but nonetheless annoying issues: sometimes (give or take once every few minutes, sometimes way more often) the game freezes in an annoying way, in that when it starts running again, everything is being fast forwarded, which can be fatal while fighting strong enemies (especially for squishier character builds - I was lucky enough to survive few sketchy situations this has caused with my rather tanky character). I've noticed this problem occuring starting from Ragnarök.
The character gets stuck from time to time, which is also pretty annoying (f.ex. teleporting back from town directly on an opened chest or randomly getting stuck during Tiamat fight in Atlantis).
It is very difficult to click on some of the portals (f.ex. in Outer Atlantis).
Another annoyance is that Windows button becomes disabled after alt-tabbing (and the game running in background).
There is also a somewhat rare sound glitch where more and more sound effects begin to gradually  disappear. To solve this you need to restart the game.

To be fair there is also a lot to like about the game, one of the obvious things being the whole mythological setting. The itemisation is also very nice (I especially love 'Monster Infrequents', which are item drops exclusive to specific enemy types and what is cool about them is that when a given monster can drop it, you might be able to see said item being worn/carried by the enemy!). Also this game has ultrawide support (32:9) and works great in this aspect ratio apart from minor animation glitches outside of standard 16:9 view (frozen monster animations, t-posing NPCs, which honestly gives me a chuckle, so no biggie here).

So yeah, to sum up, it's one of these reviews where "I'd love to give this game a positive score but I simply can't"...

PS: Also, whoever came up with the idea of adding trapped Majestic Chests with little to no loot (found in Ragnarök and onwards) is an evil person...

The game is great until you get to Typhon
Let me explain: back when the game first came out the base campaign had a final boss that worked just fine, except a few people used to brag about how easily they could defeat him, so the developers, who just couldn't let this fly, had the brilliant idea to remove entirely the mechanic that allowed you to beat him (the breakable statues), so that now you HAVE to tank him, which is impossible unless you happen to have extraordinary gear or you're willing to commit to an absurd amount of grinding and possibly changing your entire build and playstile

Titan Quest is a classic of its time, but as a new player, the gameplay felt incredibly restrictive—like playing with handcuffs on. The graphics still hold up surprisingly well, and the mythological setting is enjoyable, but I just couldn’t bring myself to get into it. If you’re looking for more action and less mindless clicking, I wouldn’t recommend it.

Two disclaimers before I start my rant: If giving mixed score was possible in Steam reviews I would rather choose that instead. Also, my 'review' is based on melee character (conqueror) gameplay.

One of my biggest gripes with this otherwise pretty decent game is that it sometimes feels incredibly clunky. What I mean is you are forced to use 'Stationary Attack' button if you want to relatively reliably target and hit enemies that are either small or very mobile (and sometimes also large ones due to much smaller hitbox than what you would expect). Another clunkiness example would be that character stops attacking (while holding LMB) after using War Horn skill - you can see where I'm going - you need to retarget enemies which can be a hassle (and you waste all the precious time during which enemies are stunned). I've also had an impression that it's way harder to target enemies when entering Colossus Form.
There is also a bunch of other minor, but nonetheless annoying issues: sometimes (give or take once every few minutes, sometimes way more often) the game freezes in an annoying way, in that when it starts running again, everything is being fast forwarded, which can be fatal while fighting strong enemies (especially for squishier character builds - I was lucky enough to survive few sketchy situations this has caused with my rather tanky character). I've noticed this problem occuring starting from Ragnarök.
The character gets stuck from time to time, which is also pretty annoying (f.ex. teleporting back from town directly on an opened chest or randomly getting stuck during Tiamat fight in Atlantis).
It is very difficult to click on some of the portals (f.ex. in Outer Atlantis).
Another annoyance is that Windows button becomes disabled after alt-tabbing (and the game running in background).
There is also a somewhat rare sound glitch where more and more sound effects begin to gradually  disappear. To solve this you need to restart the game.

To be fair there is also a lot to like about the game, one of the obvious things being the whole mythological setting. The itemisation is also very nice (I especially love 'Monster Infrequents', which are item drops exclusive to specific enemy types and what is cool about them is that when a given monster can drop it, you might be able to see said item being worn/carried by the enemy!). Also this game has ultrawide support (32:9) and works great in this aspect ratio apart from minor animation glitches outside of standard 16:9 view (frozen monster animations, t-posing NPCs, which honestly gives me a chuckle, so no biggie here).

So yeah, to sum up, it's one of these reviews where "I'd love to give this game a positive score but I simply can't"...

PS: Also, whoever came up with the idea of adding trapped Majestic Chests with little to no loot (found in Ragnarök and onwards) is an evil person...

Titan Quest — A Mythic Journey That Demands Patience and Precision

I was never really a fan of the Titan Quest series — I always preferred the dark, gothic atmosphere of Diablo II. Though, to be fair, I never managed to actually finish Diablo II — not as a kid, and not even now. It’s just that hard.

But Titan Quest? It’s tough in its own way. The game may look bright and mythological compared to Diablo’s hellish tone, but don’t be fooled — it can be just as punishing. One mistake in your build, and your entire playthrough can fall apart. There’s no mercy if you misplace your skill points or pick the wrong class combo.

Back in the day, that challenge felt exciting — like a puzzle to solve. But now, when you’re an adult with less free time, endless farming and trial-and-error builds just don’t hit the same way.

It’s still a great game, rich with mythological charm and classic ARPG vibes — but these days, it’s much easier to relax with something lighter, like Diablo III.
